segment.source: Handle URI activation
segment.target: Handle URI activation

segment.source: Learn how to register an app to become the default handler for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme name.
segment.target: Learn how to register an app to become the default handler for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme name.

segment.source: Handle URI activation
segment.target: Handle URI activation

segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.ApplicationModel.Activation.ProtocolActivatedEventArgs
segment.target: Windows.ApplicationModel.Activation.ProtocolActivatedEventArgs

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Application.OnActivated
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Application.OnActivated

segment.source: Learn how to register an app to become the default handler for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme name.
segment.target: Learn how to register an app to become the default handler for a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme name.

segment.source: Both Classic Windows Platform (CWP) apps and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can register to be a default handler for a URI scheme name.
segment.target: Both Classic Windows Platform (CWP) apps and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can register to be a default handler for a URI scheme name.

segment.source: If the user chooses your app as the default handler for a URI scheme name, your app will be activated every time that type of URI is launched.
segment.target: If the user chooses your app as the default handler for a URI scheme name, your app will be activated every time that type of URI is launched.

segment.source: We recommend that you only register for a URI scheme name if you expect to handle all URI launches for that type of URI scheme.
segment.target: We recommend that you only register for a URI scheme name if you expect to handle all URI launches for that type of URI scheme.

segment.source: If you do choose to register for a URI scheme name, you must provide the end user with the functionality that is expected when your app is activated for that URI scheme.
segment.target: If you do choose to register for a URI scheme name, you must provide the end user with the functionality that is expected when your app is activated for that URI scheme.

segment.source: For example, an app that registers for the mailto: URI scheme name should open to a new e-mail message so that the user can compose a new e-mail.
segment.target: For example, an app that registers for the mailto: URI scheme name should open to a new e-mail message so that the user can compose a new e-mail.

segment.source: For more info on URI associations, see Guidelines and checklist for file types and URIs.
segment.target: For more info on URI associations, see Guidelines and checklist for file types and URIs.

segment.source: These steps show how to register for a custom URI scheme name, alsdk://, and how to activate your app when the user launches a alsdk:// URI.
segment.target: These steps show how to register for a custom URI scheme name, alsdk://, and how to activate your app when the user launches a alsdk:// URI.

segment.source: Note In UWP apps, certain URIs and file extensions are reserved for use by built-in apps and the operating system.
segment.target: Note In UWP apps, certain URIs and file extensions are reserved for use by built-in apps and the operating system.

segment.source: Attempts to register your app with a reserved URI or file extension will be ignored.
segment.target: Attempts to register your app with a reserved URI or file extension will be ignored.

segment.source: See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of Uri schemes that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.
segment.target: See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of Uri schemes that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.

segment.source: Step 1: Specify the extension point in the package manifest
segment.target: Step 1: Specify the extension point in the package manifest

segment.source: The app receives activation events only for the URI scheme names listed in the package manifest.
segment.target: The app receives activation events only for the URI scheme names listed in the package manifest.

segment.source: Here's how you indicate that your app handles the URI scheme name.
segment.target: Here's how you indicate that your app handles the URI scheme name.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest to open the manifest designer.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest to open the manifest designer.

segment.source: Select the Declarations tab and in the Available Declarations drop-down, select Protocol and then click Add.
segment.target: Select the Declarations tab and in the Available Declarations drop-down, select Protocol and then click Add.

segment.source: Here is a brief description of each of the fields that you may fill in the manifest designer for the Protocol (see AppX Package Manifest for details):
segment.target: Here is a brief description of each of the fields that you may fill in the manifest designer for the Protocol (see AppX Package Manifest for details):

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Logo
segment.target: Logo

segment.source: Specify the logo that is used to identify the URI scheme name in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.
segment.target: Specify the logo that is used to identify the URI scheme name in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.

segment.source: If no Logo is specified, the small logo for the app is used.
segment.target: If no Logo is specified, the small logo for the app is used.

segment.source: Display Name
segment.target: Display Name

segment.source: Specify the display name to identify the URI scheme name in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.
segment.target: Specify the display name to identify the URI scheme name in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.

segment.source: Name
segment.target: Name

segment.source: Choose a name for the Uri scheme.
segment.target: Choose a name for the Uri scheme.

segment.source: Note The Name must be in all lower case letters.
segment.target: Note The Name must be in all lower case letters.

segment.source: Reserved and forbidden file types See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of Uri schemes that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.
segment.target: Reserved and forbidden file types See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of Uri schemes that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.

segment.source: Executable
segment.target: Executable

segment.source: Specifies the default launch executable for the protocol.
segment.target: Specifies the default launch executable for the protocol.

segment.source: If not specified, the app's executable is used.
segment.target: If not specified, the app's executable is used.

segment.source: If specified, the string must be between 1 and 256 characters in length, must end with ".exe", and cannot contain these characters: , , :, ", |, ?, or \*.
segment.target: If specified, the string must be between 1 and 256 characters in length, must end with ".exe", and cannot contain these characters: , , :, ", |, ?, or \*.

segment.source: If specified, the Entry point is also used.
segment.target: If specified, the Entry point is also used.

segment.source: If the Entry point isn't specified, the entry point defined for the app is used.
segment.target: If the Entry point isn't specified, the entry point defined for the app is used.

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Entry point
segment.target: Entry point

segment.source: Specifies the task that handles the protocol extension.
segment.target: Specifies the task that handles the protocol extension.

segment.source: This is normally the fully namespace-qualified name of a Windows Runtime type.
segment.target: This is normally the fully namespace-qualified name of a Windows Runtime type.

segment.source: If not specified, the entry point for the app is used.
segment.target: If not specified, the entry point for the app is used.

segment.source: Start page
segment.target: Start page

segment.source: The web page that handles the extensibility point.
segment.target: The web page that handles the extensibility point.

segment.source: Resource group
segment.target: Resource group

segment.source: A tag that you can use to group extension activations together for resource management purposes.
segment.target: A tag that you can use to group extension activations together for resource management purposes.

segment.source: Desired View (Windows-only)
segment.target: Desired View (Windows-only)

segment.source: Specify the Desired View field to indicate the amount of space the app's window needs when it is launched for the URI scheme name.
segment.target: Specify the Desired View field to indicate the amount of space the app's window needs when it is launched for the URI scheme name.

segment.source: The possible values for Desired View are Default, UseLess, UseHalf, UseMore, or UseMinimum.
segment.target: The possible values for Desired View are Default, UseLess, UseHalf, UseMore, or UseMinimum.

segment.source: Note Windows takes into account multiple different factors when determining the target app's final window size, for example, the preference of the source app, the number of apps on screen, the screen orientation, and so on.
segment.target: Note Windows takes into account multiple different factors when determining the target app's final window size, for example, the preference of the source app, the number of apps on screen, the screen orientation, and so on.

segment.source: Setting Desired View doesn't guarantee a specific windowing behavior for the target app.
segment.target: Setting Desired View doesn't guarantee a specific windowing behavior for the target app.

segment.source: Mobile device family: Desired View isn't supported on the mobile device family.
segment.target: Mobile device family: Desired View isn't supported on the mobile device family.

segment.source: Enter as the Logo.
segment.target: Enter as the Logo.

segment.source: Enter as the Display name
segment.target: Enter as the Display name

segment.source: Enter as the Name.
segment.target: Enter as the Name.

segment.source: Press Ctrl+S to save the change to package.appxmanifest.
segment.target: Press Ctrl+S to save the change to package.appxmanifest.

segment.source: This adds an Extension element like this one to the package manifest.
segment.target: This adds an Extension element like this one to the package manifest.

segment.source: The windows.protocol category indicates that the app handles the URI scheme name.
segment.target: The windows.protocol category indicates that the app handles the URI scheme name.

segment.source: Step 2: Add the proper icons
segment.target: Step 2: Add the proper icons

segment.source: Apps that become the default for a URI scheme name have their icons displayed in various places throughout the system, for example, in the Default programs control panel.
segment.target: Apps that become the default for a URI scheme name have their icons displayed in various places throughout the system, for example, in the Default programs control panel.

segment.source: We recommend that you include the proper icons with your project so that your logo looks great in all of these places.
segment.target: We recommend that you include the proper icons with your project so that your logo looks great in all of these places.

segment.source: Match the look of the app tile logo and use your app's background color rather than making the icon transparent.
segment.target: Match the look of the app tile logo and use your app's background color rather than making the icon transparent.

segment.source: Have the logo extend to the edge without padding it.
segment.target: Have the logo extend to the edge without padding it.

segment.source: Test your icons on white backgrounds.
segment.target: Test your icons on white backgrounds.

segment.source: For example icons, see the Association launching sample.
segment.target: For example icons, see the Association launching sample.

segment.source: the solution explorer with a view of the files in the images folder.
segment.target: the solution explorer with a view of the files in the images folder.

segment.source: there are 16, 32, 48, and 256 pixel versions of both 'icon.targetsize' and 'smalltile-sdk'
segment.target: there are 16, 32, 48, and 256 pixel versions of both 'icon.targetsize' and 'smalltile-sdk'

segment.source: Step 3: Handle the activated event
segment.target: Step 3: Handle the activated event

segment.source: The OnActivated event handler receives all activation events.
segment.target: The OnActivated event handler receives all activation events.

segment.source: The Kind property indicates the type of activation event.
segment.target: The Kind property indicates the type of activation event.

segment.source: This example is set up to handle Protocol activation events.
segment.target: This example is set up to handle Protocol activation events.

segment.source: Note When launched via Protocol Contract, make sure that Back button takes the user back to the screen that launched the app and not to the app's previous content.
segment.target: Note When launched via Protocol Contract, make sure that Back button takes the user back to the screen that launched the app and not to the app's previous content.

segment.source: It is recommended that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new page.
segment.target: It is recommended that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new page.

segment.source: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.
segment.target: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.

segment.source: Apps that decide to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and File Contracts should clear the pages on the Frame navigation journal before navigating to a new page.
segment.target: Apps that decide to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and File Contracts should clear the pages on the Frame navigation journal before navigating to a new page.

segment.source: When launched via Protocol activation, apps should consider including UI that allows the user to go back to the top page of the app.
segment.target: When launched via Protocol activation, apps should consider including UI that allows the user to go back to the top page of the app.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: Any app or website can use your URI scheme name, including malicious ones.
segment.target: Any app or website can use your URI scheme name, including malicious ones.

segment.source: So any data that you get in the URI could come from an untrusted source.
segment.target: So any data that you get in the URI could come from an untrusted source.

segment.source: We recommend that you never perform a permanent action based on the parameters that you receive in the URI.
segment.target: We recommend that you never perform a permanent action based on the parameters that you receive in the URI.

segment.source: For example, URI parameters could be used to launch the app to a user's account page, but we recommend that you never use them to directly modify the user's account.
segment.target: For example, URI parameters could be used to launch the app to a user's account page, but we recommend that you never use them to directly modify the user's account.

segment.source: Note If you are creating a new URI scheme name for your app, be sure to follow the guidance in RFC 4395.
segment.target: Note If you are creating a new URI scheme name for your app, be sure to follow the guidance in RFC 4395.

segment.source: This ensures that your name meets the standards for URI schemes.
segment.target: This ensures that your name meets the standards for URI schemes.

segment.source: Note When launched via Protocol Contract, make sure that Back button takes the user back to the screen that launched the app and not to the app's previous content.
segment.target: Note When launched via Protocol Contract, make sure that Back button takes the user back to the screen that launched the app and not to the app's previous content.

segment.source: We recommend that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new Uri target.
segment.target: We recommend that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new Uri target.

segment.source: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.
segment.target: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.

segment.source: If you decide that you want your apps to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and Protocol Contracts, clear the pages on the Frame navigation journal before navigating to a new page.
segment.target: If you decide that you want your apps to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and Protocol Contracts, clear the pages on the Frame navigation journal before navigating to a new page.

segment.source: When launched via Protocol Contract, consider including UI into your apps that allows the user to go back to the top of the app.
segment.target: When launched via Protocol Contract, consider including UI into your apps that allows the user to go back to the top of the app.

segment.source: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you're developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you're developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
